Schools have been open for class X and XII students to complete their exams.    All schools across the country are to open on April 25th to allow children to attain full immunity after the second dose of vaccination in the first week of April.    https://archive.ph/7bB3Z

Schools of Classes VII, VIII, IX, X and XII opened on April 4th.    Primary schools (Classes PP to VI) opened on April 18. However, children who are unvaccinated, and the day care and ECCD centres, were asked to wait for another 10 days to resume.    All colleges and institutions opened on April 4 or soon after, based on the preparation time required.    Instructions on school reopening were released by MOH on April 4th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220508191425/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/04-02-22-%F0%9D%90%91%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A9%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%A0-%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%9F-%F0%9D%90%92%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%A8/

Bhutan is gradually opening up.  Except for the entertainment centers all business entities, including snooker and video game parlors can operate with 9 PM as the revised curfew. Gym, yoga, and similar fitness centers can open for clients residing within the same mega-zone. In Thimphu, all private and public firms, companies, and agencies can open with 25 percent of the total staff.  All private and public offices in the Dzongkhags that have remained closed so far must open starting from Monday, 21st March. All offices are to be fully operational by 11th April.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

Gym, yoga, and similar fitness centers can open for clients residing within the same mega-zone. In Thimphu, all private and public firms, companies, and agencies can open with 25 percent of the total staff. Further relaxation measures were announced on April 4, 2022.    All meetings, seminars and trainings are to be conducted virtually. Physical gathering is discouraged. The entertainment centers will remain closed until further notice.    https://archive.ph/pyvOm

Bhutan has a plan for new phase of COVID 19 management. Public events are not allowed.    April 25: all sporting events will be allowed without spectators    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

Relaxation measures are continuing as Bhutan opens up.    As of March 28th, all indoor and outdoor sporting activities will be permitted but without spectators. Tournaments are not allowed for now. Individuals showing symptoms of COVID-19 are discouraged from taking part in any sporting activity.    Archery and khuru are allowed but must be kept at a maximum of 10 players per match, until the final relaxation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

There are no specific stay-at-home and gatherings requirements as restrictions are easing in Bhutan.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/

There are no restrictions on gatherings as measures continue to be relaxed in Bhutan.    https://archive.ph/pyvOm    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

Taxis could ferry people within the mega zone and identified government, corporate and private employees could attend from their offices. In addition to taxis, the movement of private cars within the respective mega-zone is allowed. Those who need to drive beyond the mega-zone for emergency reasons must produce documents or any evidence for verification on the ground.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

As of March 28, all public transport services must resume its routine schedule.    Further relaxation measures were announced on April 01,2022    Escort services for people travelling via India will continue until the international quarantine remains. But for convenience of our public, frequency of escort services will be increased. The testing requirement for all essential drivers will be discontinued.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/    https://archive.ph/pyvOm

There are no specific stay-at-home and gatherings requirements as restrictions are easing in Bhutan but government recommends staying at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418152458/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/

There are no specific stay-at-home requirements except those testing positive are advised to self-isolate at home.    Caution is being recommended. We would like to request everyone to maintain caution as far as possible. We reiterate that Omicron is milder in comparison to earlier variants, but this does not mean it is âmildâ.    https://archive.ph/pyvOm

All inter-district travels are allowed. Domestic travelers from high-risk areas and districts can now undergo home quarantine and not facility quarantine. The quarantine duration is seven days until further notice.    https://archive.ph/7bB3Z

Relaxation measures continue to be introduced in Bhutan.    As of April 4th, The mandatory quarantine and testing for domestic travellers from high-risk areas are being withdrawn hereon. The high-risk areas include Thimphu, Wangduephodrang, Dukti chiwog under Yallang gewog and Jangphutse-Manam villages under Toedtsho gewog in Trashiyangtse, Merak and Sakteng gewogs in Trashigang and all bordering areas in southern Bhutan. They need not undergo home quarantine, either at place of origin or destination. Individuals who have entered home quarantine on or before April 3 will be allowed to travel on the enforcement date.     https://archive.ph/pyvOm

For the international travellers, the lift of the 5 days quarantine will depend on the global lifting of the pandemic as per the Prime Minister. According to the Foreign Minister and Chairman of the Tourism Council of Bhutan (TCB), the country may allow quarantine-free entry by autumn this year should the situation continue to improve.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220418153321/https://www.dailybhutan.com/article/a-detailed-summary-of-bhutans-covid-19-management-and-plans-moving-forward

As of April 04th, for international travellers, the mandatory 14-day quarantine period is being brought down to ???????? ???????? ???????????????? ????????????????????.  Individuals who are already in quarantine and complete five days on April 5 will be allowed to exit based on the revised quarantine protocol.    https://archive.ph/pyvOm

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grants for individuals directly affected by the pandemic (now extended until June 2022) and a full interest waiver on loans contracted from April 10, 2020, until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waivers will continue until June 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220418154933/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

PCR and/or antigen tests are generally available at the numerous flu clinics located throughout Bhutan.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220418151758/https://in.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/bhutan-affairs/american-citizen-services-information/

The health ministry along with the Drug Regulatory Authority (DRA) has approved the use of COVID-19 antigen self-test kits in the country. The ministry approved the emergency use of the test kit as an increasing number of people are able to access it. Pharmacies registered with the DRA will be allowed to sell or distribute self-test kits.    However, individuals testing positive on self-test kits must report to 1010 for registration and monitoring by the clinical teams. The ministry will then facilitate immediate follow-up for vulnerable groups and monitor long COVID conditions.    Currently, there are around 60 COVID-19 testing centres across the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220429191007/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=167880    https://web.archive.org/web/20220508193319/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/11-04-22-%F0%9D%97%A5%F0%9D%97%B2%F0%9D%97%BD%F0%9D%97%BC%F0%9D%97%BF%F0%9D%98%81%F0%9D%97%B6%F0%9D%97%BB%F0%9D%97%B4-%F0%9D%97%BC%F0%9D%97%B3-%F0%9D%97%96%F0%9D%97%A2%F0%9D%97%A9%F0%9D%97%9C/

Vaccines are available for everyone above the age of 18 years. After vaccinating 12-16-year-old children, Bhutan is in the process of vaccinating 5-11-year-old children and providing booster doses to children 12-16 years old. Vaccines that have been approved include Covishield (AstraZeneca), Moderna, Pfizer BioNTech, and Sinopharm and they are fully funded by the Govt.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220418151636/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bhutan/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418160519/https://www.moh.gov.bt/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418161150/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/24-03-33-covid-19-booster-vaccination-for-children-12-to-17-years-old/

Vaccines are available for everyone above the age of 18 years. Bhutan has run a vaccination campaign for 12-16-year-old children, followed by 5-11-year-old children and providing booster doses to children 12-16 years old.     On April 18th, the health ministry rolled out the second booster or the fourth dose for those in the priority groups. The priority groups include the elderly above 65 years, persons with chronic medical conditions, all health workers, frontline workers and all outbound travellers above the age of 18. As per the ministry, close to 230,000 people are in the priority group.    Vaccines that have been approved include Covishield (AstraZeneca), Moderna, Pfizer BioNTech, and Sinopharm and they are fully funded by the Govt.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220418151636/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bhutan/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418160519/https://www.moh.gov.bt/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418161150/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/24-03-33-covid-19-booster-vaccination-for-children-12-to-17-years-old/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220429190649/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=168108
COVID 19 vaccines and boosters were prioritized for the elderly. There is a COVID 19 hotline for senior citizens.    https://archive.ph/5gbLt

COVID 19 vaccines and boosters were prioritized for the elderly.  There is a COVID 19 hotline for senior citizens    https://web.archive.org/web/20210527034238/http://www.moh.gov.bt/announcement-senior-citizens/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220429190649/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=168108
No change recorded.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220509163408/https://graphics.reuters.com/world-coronavirus-tracker-and-maps/countries-and-territories/sri-lanka/

No change recorded. Workplaces may function at full strength. However, authorities may enact stricter rules in areas at high risk for COVID-19 transmission. Nonessential businesses, except for specifically permitted industries, must close in these localities.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220509161914/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

No change recorded. Authorities continue to encourage people to remain at home to the extent possible. Public gatherings remain banned, though enforcement and adherence vary by region.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509161914/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

No change recorded. Authorities continue to encourage people to remain at home to the extent possible. Public gatherings remain banned, though enforcement and adherence vary by region.  Gampaha District limits participation in permitted gatherings like weddings to fully vaccinated people; other regions may enact similar curbs ahead of a proposed nationwide mandate for vaccination cards to enter most public venues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509161914/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

No change recorded. Authorities continue to encourage people to remain at home to the extent possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509161914/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

No change recorded. Public transport vehicles can run at 75 percent capacity with protocols, such as requiring all passengers to be seated and wear facemasks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509161914/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

No change recorded. Fully vaccinated passengers are exempt from any on-arrival test or quarantine. Unvaccinated arrivals above 12 years old must take an on-arrival test, quarantine at home or a designated facility until the seventh day of arrival, and undergo an exit PCR or RAT test.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220509161914/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/sri-lanka-officials-no-longer-require-pre-departure-covid-19-tests-for-fully-vaccinated-entrants-from-march-1-update-81

PCR and/or antigen tests available in Sri Lanka.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509165030/https://lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Face masks must be worn in public.    https://archive.ph/V5v8E
Government offers COVID-19 vaccines free for everyone in Sri Lanka.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220509165842/http://www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/others.php?pid=233

There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal with a vaccination certificate. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html

Vaccinated visitors must present a certificate showing a negative RT-PCR test, taken within 72 hours of flight of first departure. According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has approved 5 vaccine (Astrazeneca, Stupnik V, Covaxin, Sinovac, Sinopharm). See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018181222/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    21 more million doses to be delivered before June 2022:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/    According to MoH Nepal, as of early April 2022, 75.8% of the population have received the 1st dose and 66.2% are fully vaccinated. Abour 8.1% of the population has received a booster.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html

All citizens aged over 12 years old are eligible to receive COVID-19 vaccines. For boosters shot eligibility criteria as follows:  1.	Immunocompromised persons of all eligible age groups  2.	Citizen, 30 years of age and above  3.	Healthcare workers.  For age group 12-18 years old only Pfizer vaccine is administered.   Available vaccines are Sinopharm, Sinovac, Pfizer and Moderna.   Vaccine is free for unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220502202916/https://covid.gov.pk/vaccine-details
